class orquestra.quantum.measurements.ExpectationValues(values: numpy.ndarray, correlations: Optional[List[numpy.ndarray]] = None, estimator_covariances: Optional[List[numpy.ndarray]] = None)#

A class representing expectation values of operators. For more context on how it is being used, please see the docstring of EstimateExpectationValues Protocol in interfaces/estimation.py.

Parameters

  • values â€“ The expectation values of a set of terms in an IsingOperator.

  • correlations â€“ The expectation values of pairwise products of operators. Contains an NxN array for each frame, where N is the number of operators in that frame.

  • estimator_covariances â€“ The (estimated) covariances between estimates of expectation values of pairs of operators. Contains an NxN array for each frame, where N is the number of operators in that frame. Note that for direct sampling, the covariance between estimates of expectation values is equal to the population covariance divided by the number of samples.

values#

See Args.

correlations#

See Args.

estimator_covariances#

See Args.

to_dict(self) → Dict[str, Any]#

Convert to a dictionary

classmethod from_dict(cls, dictionary: dict) → ExpectationValues#

Create an ExpectationValues object from a dictionary.

orquestra.quantum.measurements.sample_from_wavefunction(wavefunction: orquestra.quantum.wavefunction.Wavefunction, n_samples: int, seed: Optional[int] = None) → List[Tuple[int, Ellipsis]]#

Sample bitstrings from a wavefunction.

Parameters

  • wavefunction â€“ the wavefunction to sample from.

  • n_samples â€“ the number of samples taken. Needs to be greater than 0.

  • seed â€“ the seed of the sampler

Returns

A list of tuples where the each tuple is a sampled bitstring.

Return type

List[Tuple[int]]

class orquestra.quantum.measurements.Parities(values: numpy.ndarray, correlations: Optional[List[numpy.ndarray]] = None)#

A class representing counts of parities for Pauli terms.

Parameters

  • values (np.array) â€“ Number of observations of parities. See Attributes.

  • correlations (list) â€“ Number of observations of pairwise products of terms. See Attributes.

values#

an array of dimension N x 2 indicating how many times each Pauli term was observed with even and odd parity, where N is the number of Pauli terms. Here values[i][0] and values[i][1] correspond to the number of samples with even and odd parities for term P_i, respectively.

Type

np.array

correlations#

a list of 3-dimensional numpy arrays indicating how many times each product of Pauli terms was observed with even and odd parity. Here correlations[i][j][k][0] and correlations[i][j][k][1] correspond to the number of samples with even and odd parities term P_j P_k in frame i, respectively.

Type

list

to_dict(self) → dict#
classmethod from_dict(cls, data: dict)#

orquestra.quantum.measurements.check_parity(bitstring: Union[str, Sequence[int]], marked_qubits: Iterable[int]) → bool#

Determine if the marked qubits have even parity for the given bitstring.

Parameters

  • bitstring â€“ The bitstring, either as a tuple or little endian string.

  • marked_qubits â€“ The qubits whose parity is to be determined.

Returns

True if an even number of the marked qubits are in the 1 state, False

otherwise.

orquestra.quantum.measurements.check_parity_of_vector(bitstrings_vector: numpy.ndarray, marked_qubits: Iterable[int]) → numpy.ndarray#
Determine if the marked qubits have even parity for each bitstring in the given

vector. NOTE: This performs the same functionality as check_parity but is much faster as it uses vectorization to find the parity of multiple bitstrings at once.

Parameters

  • bitstring â€“ A 2d array of bitstrings whose size is number of bistrings * number of qubits

  • marked_qubits â€“ The qubits whose parity is to be determined.

Returns

A 1d array with size equal to number of bitstrings. Each entry is 1 if an even number of the marked qubits of the corresponding bitstring are in the 1 state and 0 if otherwise.

orquestra.quantum.measurements.get_expectation_value_from_frequencies(marked_qubits: Iterable[int], bitstring_frequencies: Dict[str, int]) → float#

Get the expectation value the product of Z operators on selected qubits from bitstring frequencies.

Parameters

  • marked_qubits â€“ The qubits that the Z operators act on.

  • bitstring_frequences â€“ The frequencies of the bitstrings.

Returns

The expectation value of the product of Z operators on selected qubits.

class orquestra.quantum.measurements.Measurements(bitstrings: Optional[List[Tuple[int, Ellipsis]]] = None)#

A class representing measurements from a quantum circuit. The bitstrings variable represents the internal data structure of the Measurements class. It is expressed as a list of tuples wherein each tuple is a measurement and the value of the tuple at a given index is the measured bit-value of the qubit (indexed from 0 -> N-1)

classmethod from_counts(cls, counts: Dict[str, int])#

Create an instance of the Measurements class from a dictionary

Parameters

counts â€“ mapping of bitstrings to integers representing the number of times the bitstring was measured

classmethod get_measurements_representing_distribution(cls, measurement_outcome_distribution: distributions.MeasurementOutcomeDistribution, number_of_samples: int)#

Create an instance of the Measurements class that exactly (or as closely as possible) resembles the input bitstring distribution.

Parameters

  • measurement_outcome_distribution â€“ the bitstring distribution to be sampled

  • number_of_samples â€“ the number of measurements

Add measurements from a histogram

Parameters

counts â€“ mapping of bitstrings to integers representing the number of times the bitstring was measured NOTE: bitstrings are also indexed from 0 -> N-1, where the â€œ001â€ bitstring represents a measurement of qubit 2 in the 1 state

get_expectation_values(self, ising_operator, use_bessel_correction: bool = False) → ExpectationValues#

Get the expectation values of an operator from the measurements.

Parameters

  • ising_operator â€“ the operator

  • use_bessel_correction â€“ Whether to use Besselâ€™s correction when when estimating the covariance of operators. Using the correction provides an unbiased estimate for covariances, but diverges when only one sample is taken.

Returns

expectation values of each term in the operator
